occurrences.line_text: But he halfe discontent, mote nathelesse
Atin drew nigh, to weet what it mote bee;
Ne ought mote euer sinke downe to the bottome there.
With hearbs and fruits, whose kinds mote not be red:
Clothed with leaues, that none the wood mote see
Where euer that on ground they mote him fynd;
Mote I beseech to succour his sad plight,
Mote ought allay the storme of your despight,
Else mote it needes downe to his manly brest
That nothing seem'd mote beare so monstrous might:
Sir knight, mote I of you this curt'sie read,
What mote ye weene, if the trew liuely-head
Gramercy Sir (said he) but mote I wote,
Mote stead you much your purpose to subdew.
For she was faire, as faire mote euer bee,
Nor wight, nor word mote passe out of the gate,
But if ought else that I mote not deuise,
But not on ground mote like to this be found,
With these in praise of pollicies mote striue.
That nought mote hinder his quicke preiudize:
A man of yeares yet fresh, as mote appere,
Mote deeme him borne with ill disposed skyes,
That not Scuith guiridh it mote seeme to bee
Faire mote he thee, the prowest and most gent,
That mote recure their wounds: so inly they did tine.
That mote the passengers thereto allure;
Such as Dame Nature selfe mote feare to see,
Or Eden selfe, if ought with Eden mote compaire.
And those which therein bathed, mote offend.
Of all that mote delight a daintie eare,
To read, what manner musicke that mote bee:
But Palmer, if it mote thee so aggrate,
That mortall puissance mote not withstond:
Nothing on earth mote alwaies happie beene.
Which fled so fast, that nothing mote him hold,
But all spurd after fast, as they mote fly,
That neuer any mote with her compaire.
Mote Princes place beseeme so deckt to bee.
Dreadfull of daunger, that mote him betyde,
Mote breede him scath vnwares: but all in vaine;
But when she mote not thereunto be wonne,
And do her comfort, she mote algates dye.
Till she mote winne fit time for her desire,
Her wrathfull steele, that none mote it abide;
But mote I weet of you, right curteous knight,
Or euer do, that mote deseruen blame:
Her wretched dayes in dolour she mote wast,
Therein discouered was, ne ought mote pas,
Her to bethinke of, that mote to her selfe pertaine.
Was neuer such, but mote the like be found,
Ne ought it mote the noble Mayd auayle,
That of no liuing wight he mote be found,
First rooting tooke; but what thing it mote bee,
At last their wayes so fell, that they mote part
To seeke aduentures, which mote him befall,
That nought but death her dolour mote depart.
And my short blisse maligne, yet mote they well
I mote haue closed, and him bed farewell,
He mote surcease his suit, and lose the hope
Oft did he wish, that Lady faire mote bee
The Dwarfe him answerd, Sir, ill mote I stay
To seeke his Lady, where he mote her find;
For doubt of daunger, which mote him betide;
Mote algates passe; for thy, themselues they set
To seeke for hearbes, that mote him remedy;
That greatest Princes liuing it mote well delight.
Had borne him, or his tract she mote detect:
Ladies and Lords she euery where mote heare
She gan auize, where else he mote him hyde:
To your disports: ill mote ye bene apayd.
If any tract of him or tydings they mote trace.
Therefore needs mote he liue, that liuing giues to all.
That her sweet loue his malice mote auoyd,
And forst t'alight, on foot mote algates fare,
To whom approching, well he mote perceiue
To find them out. Mote I (then laughing sayd
Bad that same boaster, as he mote, on high
Ne ought your burning fury mote abate;
As an immortall mote a mortall wight,
For perdie else how mote it euer bee,
Mote not mislike you also to abate
Mote not be entertaynd, as seemed meet,
But all in vaine; for nought mote him relent,
And seru'd of all things that mote needfull bee;
That much they faynd to know, who she mote bee;
That least auantage mote to him afford,
That he mote algates dye, yet did his death forgiue.
And euery where that he mote vnderstond,
Well weened he, that those the same mote bee,
Mote him befall vpon new enterprise;
For griefe whereof, ye mote haue liuely seene
Or to them tydings tell, that mote their harts delight.
That mote to none but to the warie wise appeare.
What mote they be: who viewing them more neare
The which mote haue enriched all vs heare.
Well seene in euerie science that mote bee,
How to preuent the perill that mote rise,
Their days mote be abridged through their corage stout.
That nought mote stay the steele, till in his side
Well mote ye wonder how that noble Knight,
He open shewd, that all men it mote marke.
Yet mote he not withstand, what was decreede;
Ne Iudges powre, ne reasons rule mote them restraine.
That nought but dire reuenge his anger mote defray.
Where better seem'd he mote himselfe repose;
The signes of anguish one mote plainely read,
What is your owne, that I mote you requite?
Certes (sayd he) ye mote as now excuse
That seemed nought but death mote be her destinie.
Mote I request you tydings of my loue,
Vnto some resting place, which mote befall,
That by his grenning laughter mote farre off be rad.
Where hardly eye mote see bright heauens face,
Seeking aduentures, where he mote heare tell;
Ne ought mote make him change his wonted tenor,
Ne ought mote ease or mitigate his paine,
Where was her won, and how he mote her find.
Yet seeing not how thence he mote remoue,
ï¿½mylia well he lou'd, as I mote ghesse;
He gan aduise how best he mote darrayne
That she mote match the fairest of her daies,
That which of them was best, mote not be deemed.
Mote we entreat you, sith this gentle crew
That none mote haue accesse, nor inward fare,
But there mote find to please it selfe withall;
That in this ioyous place they mote haue ioyance free.
Nor any blemish, which the worke mote blame;
For feare of perill, which to him mote fall,
And endlesse memorie, that mote excell,
Which mote the feebled Britons strongly flancke
Oft listening if he mote her heare againe;
Admyr'd her beautie much, as she mote well:
Whom (as ye lately mote remember well)
That I mote drinke the cup, whereof she dranke:
That ill perhaps mote fall to either side.
Till he of tidings mote with him discourse.
That there mote be no hope of reparation,
She mote reuenge that blot, which on her lay.
That he mote fresher be against the next daies fight.
That to the Moone it mote be like in each respect.
Be hang'd on high, that mote his shame bewray;
Who had him seene, imagine mote thereby,
But rather how she mote him faster tye.
And his worke lessened, that his loue mote grow:
That she with him mote be the more offended.
Who when he nigh approcht, shee mote arede
Or ought to heare, that mote delightfull bee;
Into her eye, which th'heart mote haue relieued,
Now mote ye know (that which to Britomart
That if two met, the one mote needes fall ouer the lidge.
But Talus mote not be admitted to her part.
They mote the better tend to their deuotion.
Therefore they mote not taste of fleshly food,
Mote in them stirre vp old rebellious thought,
Yet mote he algates now abide, and answere make.
And sent to him a Page, that mote direct his way.
He mote not come, to wreake his wrathfull mood.
That mote remaine for an eternall token
By like ensample mote for euer warned bee.
Dealing iust iudgements, that mote not be broken
An huge great Lyon lay, that mote appall
Which that those knights likewise mote vnderstand,
Where they mote heare the matter throughly scand
Though also those mote question'd be aright,
For she whylome (as ye mote yet right well
That nought the morrow next mote stay his fare.
Vnto some place, where they mote rest and feede,
And further sayd; Ah Sir, but mote ye please,
Least ye therefore mote happily me blame,
That it to such a streight mote you constraine)
Dye rather, then doe ought, that mote dishonour yield.
Gainst which no flight nor rescue mote auayle,
To weete if shipping readie he mote there descry.
Abett, perhaps he mote it deare aby.
And that of him she mote assured stand,
And tryde all waies, how each mote entrance make
As they had potshares bene; for nought mote slake
By all the meanes she mote it best explaine:
When so she lagged, as she needs mote so,
Faire was the Ladie sure, that mote content
That mote thy kindled courage set on fire,
And as it mote a faithfull friend behoue,
And far from enuious eyes that mote him spight.
That they mote treat of things abrode at leasure;
Till to some place of rest they mote attaine,
Where she in safe assuraunce mote abide,
Ne wist which way he through the foord mote pas.
Regarding neither speare, that mote him slay,
Nor his fierce steed, that mote him much dismay,
They mote the abler be to passe vnto the rest.
Whose burden mote empeach his needfull speed,
Where looking all about, where he mote fynd
And for what cause declare, so mote ye not repent?
Till that his Ladies sight he mote attaine,
That mote to all men seeme an vncouth sight;
After aduentures, where they mote them get.
To seeke some place, the which mote yeeld some ease
Mote easie be supprest with little thing:
Vntill fit time and place he mote espy,
Where he mote worke him scath and villeny.
In which they mote make triall of their might,
Fearelesse of foes that mote his peace molest;
But when he nigh approcht, he mote aread
He doubted much what mote their meaning bee,
Ne ought it mote auaile her to entreat
What meaning mote those vncouth words comprize,
Fearelesse of ought, that mote her peace molest,
To eate the flesh of men, whom they mote fynde,
Which mote not be prophan'd of common eyes,
Now mote ye vnderstand that to this groue
He mote perceiue a litle dawning sight
Nor any wicked feend, that mote offend
That mote empaire my peace with daungers dread.
The whylest at pleasure she mote sport and play;
Ne certes mote he greatly blamed be,
Ne mote wylde beastes, ne mote the ruder clowne
Ne mote wylde beastes, ne mote the ruder clowne
Thereto approch, ne filth mote therein drowne:
He nigher drew, to weete what mote it be;
With which his eyes mote haue deluded beene.
Drew neare, that he the truth of all by him mote learne.
Tell me, what mote these dainty Damzels be,
Who can aread, what creature mote she bee,
Who rashly sought that, which I mote not see.
But wisht, that with that shepheard he mote dwelling share.
Mote him auaile, but to returne againe
Mote them descry, nor reskue from their pray,
Through hollow caues, that no man mote discouer
And sought her loue, by all the meanes he mote;
By which he mote accomplish his request,
Saying and doing all that mote behoue;
That she thereby mote either freely wend,
Mote to them for their most commodity
By meanes whereof, that mote not be amended,
He mote perceiue by signes, which he did fynd,
It could not boot, needs mote she die at last:
In hope there newes to learne, how they mote best assay.
Mote not bewray the secret of her lode,
She mote perceiue a litle purple mold,
With foule dishonour him mote blot therefore;
Askt her, how mote her words be vnderstood,
Tho when the Beast saw, he mote nought auaile,
That neuer more he mote endammadge wight
By which both in and out men moten pas;
And inly grieue, as doth an hidden moth
And with thy mother milde come to mine ayde:
With bloudy mouth his mother earth did kis,
And home she came, whereas her mother blynd
Could it discerne, though I the mother bee
The mother of dread darknesse, and let stay
His louing mother came vpon a day
The greatest Earth his vncouth mother was,
Of mother pearle, and buckled with a golden tong.
The mother of three daughters, well vpbrought
One mother, when as her foolehardie chyld
As on the earth, great mother of vs all,
Liue thou, and to thy mother dead attest,
And that same Hag, his aged mother, hight
Which kindled once, his mother did more rage inspyre.
His mother eke, more to augment his spight,
But to her mother Nature all her care she lets.
With his faire mother he him dights to play,
That their owne mother loathd their beastlinesse,
Whose death t'auenge, his mother mercilesse,
And gaue against his mother earth a gronefull sownd.
How th'Earth his mother was, and first him bore;
Wherewith her mother Art, as halfe in scorne
The louing mother, that nine monethes did beare,
His mother was the blacke-browd Cymoent,
The which his mother seeing, gan to feare
His mother bad him womens loue to hate,
The which his mother vainely did expound,
Which when his mother deare did vnderstond,
His mother swowned thrise, and the third time
The wretched sonne of wretched mother borne,
Sith other offices for mother meet
Which to his mother told, despeire she from her flong.
And oft his mother vewing his wide wound,
Night thou foule Mother of annoyance sad,
For Ladies loue his mother long ygoe
Her mother was the faire Chrysogonee,
And their great mother Venus did lament
With which his mother Venus her reuyld,
Sitting beside his mother on the ground;
Softly at last he gan his mother aske,
That his sad mother seeing his sore plight,
Through incest, her of his owne mother Earth
And in his rage his mother would haue slaine,
And scoffing, thus vnto his mother sayd,
His owne deare mother, (ah why should he so?)
From thy sweete smyling mother from aboue,
Her name was Ate, mother of debate,
Borne of one mother in one happie mold,
Thrise happie mother, and thrise happie morne,
Their mother was, and had full blessed hap,
Their mother was a Fay, and had the skill
Which when their mother saw, she gan to dout
Like as his mother prayd the Destinie,
And well instructed by the Fay her mother,
Which of great mother Venus bare the name,
For all that nature by her mother wit
The Queene of beautie, and of loue the mother,
Begotten by two fathers of one mother,
Mother of blessed Peace, and Friendship trew;
She syre and mother is her selfe alone,
And thee their mother call to coole their kindly rages.
Mother of laughter, and welspring of blisse,
Yet farre and neare the Nymph his mother sought,
There with the Nymph his mother, like her thrall;
Like as the mother of the Gods, they say,
My mother Cambridge, whom as with a Crowne
And there amongst the rest, the mother was
The Nymph his mother getteth her,
The mother of vnlucky Marinell,
Yet durst he not his mother disobay,
Which when his mother saw, she in her mind
Which when he had vnto his mother told,
It had depriu'd her mother of a daughter.
But on their mother Earths deare lap did lie,
Or as that madding mother, mongst the rout
Sent by their mother, who a widow was,
And mother of a frutefull heritage,
More happie mother would her surely weene,
That downe he fell vppon his mother deare,
That falling on his mother earth he fed:
The widow Queene my mother, which then hight
The sober mother seeing such her mood,
Who euer is the mother of one chylde,
And sucked vp their dying mothers blood,
In hart, and chaunge in that great mothers face:
Out of his mothers bowelles, and it made
Do for the milkie mothers want complaine,
From mothers pap I taken was vnfit:
That they his mothers innocence may tell,
The children of one sire by mothers three;
For from my mothers wombe this grace I haue
Tydings hereof came to his mothers eare;
Yet he his mothers lore did well retaine,
Whiles in their mothers wombe enclosd they were,
That thou bewray'dst his mothers wantonnesse,
In vengement of her mothers great disgrace,
A God of seas through his mad mothers blame,
But then he fear'd his mothers former charge
Being returned to his mothers bowre,
For from his mothers wombe, which him did beare
In her owne breast, this mothers ioy descriue:
And all her vitall powres with motion nimble,
Which was short tucked for light motion
Tho mou'd with wrath, and shame, and Ladies sake,
And faint through losse of bloud, mou'd not at all,
The noble Guyon mou'd with great remorse,
And mou'd amisse with massie mucks vnmeet regard.
That in the idle aire he mou'd still here and there.
That many of them mou'd to eye her sore.
That mou'd Belphebe her no lesse to hate,
That being mou'd with ruth she thus bespake.
Who mou'd no more therewith, then when a rocke
But he was nothing mou'd, nor tempted therewithall.
He much was mou'd at so vnworthie shame,
Of my mishaps, art mou'd to wish me better,
But when they mou'd the carcases aside,
And what the matter was, that mou'd her so.
And with that suddein horror could no member moue.
If from their loyall loues he might then moue;
From wandring Stygian shores, where it doth endlesse moue.
Ne word to speake, ne ioynt to moue she had:
The souldier may not moue from watchfull sted,
To moue the world from off his stedfast henge,
Her loued knight to moue his manly pace:
Another said, he saw him moue his eyes indeed.
Which when he felt to moue, he hoped faire
She could them nimbly moue, and after fly apace.
That might him moue to wrath, and indignation reare.
When I should see, that would me nearer moue,
That in thy selfe thy lesser parts do moue,
That might to her moue cause of meriment:
That may compassion of their euils moue?
Did not once moue, nor vpward cast his eye,
Not that same, which doth base affections moue
Ne foot could further moue: the Lady gent
To moue, and tremble as it were agast,
And with her feeble feet did moue a comely pace.
With which vaine termes so much they did the[m]; moue,
That oftentimes vnquiet strife did moue
Those Pensifenesse did moue; and Sighes the bellows weare.
That trusty Squire he wisely well did moue
But lusted after all, that him did moue.
To speake to them, and some emparlance moue;
Her constant mind could moue at all he saw,
Like ruefull ghost, vnable once to stirre or moue.
And all this world with them amisse doe moue,
Moue Radigund? who though she still haue worne
Which inly did to great impatience moue her.
Her wand did moue with amiable looke,
That once he could not moue, nor quich at all;
That Calidore it dearly deepe did moue.
Declar'd the message, which that Knight did moue;
To moue one foote, but there must make abode;
Ne any will had thence to moue away,
Which round about her moue in order excellent.
Her feeling speeches some compassion moued
He would not once haue moued for the knight.
The king was greatly moued at her speach,
The knight was greatly moued at his plaint,
Though somewhat moued in his mightie hart,
The Prince was inly moued at her speach,
She ouerhent, nought moued with her piteous looke.
Her fearfull feete towards the bowre she moued;
He nought was moued at their entrance bold:
In mischiefe, was much moued at so pitteous sight.
But she no more was moued with that might,
Purpose was moued by that gentle Dame,
Ne euer was with fond affection moued,
Moued with pity of her plenteous teares.
But most was moued at the piteous vew
I neuer ioyed howre, but still with care was moued.
That ruth it moued in the rocky stone,
Much was he moued at that ruefull sight;
Thereof great hurly burly moued was
Much was she moued with the mightie sway
Were moued much thereat, and twixt them fained,
Much was he moued with her piteous plight,
With great admiraunce inwardly was moued,
Much was I moued in indignant mind,
And moued speach to him of things of course,
Yet flowing fresh, as moued with the sight,
Wherewith the Prince sore moued, there auoud,
That moues more deare compassion of mind,
His artes he moues, and out of caytiues hands
And dayly warre against his foeman moues,
Might wanting measure moueth surquedry.
So sound he slept, that nought mought him awake.
He gan deuise, how her he reskew mought,
And meekest boone, that they imagine mought.
And fled away with all the speede she mought,
Which doubt of daunger to her offer mought,
And a quicke mouing Spirit did arret
But feard each shadow mouing to and fro,
So left her, where she now is turnd to treen mould.
But full great pittie, that so faire a mould
Or liking find to gaze on earthly mould,
The wretched payre transform'd to treen mould;
It framed was, one massie entire mould,
The wondrous workemanship of Gods owne mould,
A worke of rich entayle, and curious mould,
But he himselfe was all of golden mould,
Ne mortall steele emperce his miscreated mould.
And all his armour seem'd of antique mould,
Now ranckleth in this same fraile fleshly mould,
And fetch their being from the sacred mould
Was purest snow in massie mould congeald,
All three to each vnlike, yet all made in one mould.
Eftsoones out sprung two more of equall mould;
Of earthly mould, and form'd of flesh and bone,
His name was Talus, made of yron mould,
Whose character in th'Adamantine mould
Of his rich mould, did thrust it farre away,
There where the mouldred earth had cav'd the banke;
Nor shining gold, nor mouldring clay it was;
Ne can the man, that moulds in idle cell,
Of this great gardin, compast with a mound,
From sea to sea he heapt a mightie mound,
And to the Presence mount; whose glorious vew
And shooting in the earth, casts vp a mount of clay.
That done, he leads him to the highest Mount;
Or like that pleasaunt Mount, that is for ay
And striues to mount vnto his natiue seat;
There stood a stately Mount, on whose round top
Hewen vnderneath that Mount, that none him losen may.
Vpon the top of Mount Olympus hight,
On Acidalian mount, where many an howre
But like a little Mount of small degree;
When he was readie to his steede to mount
Therefore it rightly cleeped was mount Acidale.
Vnder the steepe foot of a mountaine hore;
Scattered on euery mountaine, as he went,
As mountaine doth the valley ouercast.
So downe he fell, and like an heaped mountaine lay.
The surging waters like a mountaine rise,
And eke huge mountaines from their natiue seat
And ragged ribs of mountaines molten new,
Through woods & mountaines, till they came at last
At thy commaund lo all these mountaines bee;
From the high mountaines, threats to ouerflow
Betwixt two shadie mountaines doth arize;
Shall to the vtmost mountaines fly apace:
And thy moyst mountaines each on others throng,
Through thick and thin, through mountaines & through plains,
With mountaines round about enuironed,
Faire Ister, flowing from the mountaines hie;
Therefore I will throw downe these mountaines hie,
Through woods, and rocks, and mountaines they did draw
Through thick and thin, through mountains & through plains,
Then mounted he vpon his Steede againe,
Now when Aldeboran was mounted hie
And fall away, it mounted was full hie,
High mounted on her manyheaded beast,
And lightly mounted, passeth on his way,
Thought to haue mounted, but his feeble vaines
Was mounted high in top of heauen sheene,
